summary: Passed in 2009, the Kissell Amendment restricts the Department of Homeland Security to procuring uniforms and other textiles from U.S. manufacturers, with certain exceptions. DHS has incorporated the restriction into its procurement policies and practices. But we found, due in part to the exceptions, that the restriction has limited effect. For example, procurements must be made in accordance with U.S. trade agreements, which means most...
title: Government Procurement: Effect of Restriction on DHS's Purchasing of Foreign Textiles Is Limited
